review: I have this Chromecast as well a Roku (2XS).  They both have advantages and I love my Roku, but I this will work great for most users.Long story short if you don't wish to go into pros/cons:  Check to see if the service you use (Netflix, Hulu etc) support Chromecast. If you have no issues with the Wi-Fi in your home and if you don't need a remote control, then this should suffice.Pros1. It's easy and works with your tablet or phone.  If you're watching Netflix or YouTube, just tap the 'cast' button and now it's on your TV.  Tap it again to disconnect.  And, you can still use your phone/tablet for other functions while it streams.2.3. It's small.  Just plug it into the TV and give it power.  Newer TV's can power it from the built in USB port in the TV (check your TV manual for functionality)4. It's $35.  I don't think it gets cheaper.5. Expanded support for a lot of apps now.  more apps are being supported all the time.6. No remote control, since you control everything from your phone/tabletCons1. No remote control.  I find older users aren't comfortable with this.2. All Wi-fi, no wired options.  This is fine for most with today's routers, but I seem to have occasional wi-fi signal issues that I think is due to interference.  So once in a while, my stream is low-res or choppy, but this is not the fault of Chromecast
